Description: Mould-made round-bodid pottery oil-lamp with a heart-shaped nozzle, decorated on the discus with the relief of reclining/squatting figure (Harpocrates?). The shoulder is decorated with an incised ring. At the rear is a vertical ring handle. The oil-lamp base indicated by incised line. Coarse organic orange-brown Nile silt. Eroded, no trace of slip remaining.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallel from Naukratis, Boston RES.86.123). Parallels in the British Museum include ovule patterning and animal subjects on earlier 75AD to 200AD handle-less lamps (Bailey 1988, British Museum Lamps III, Q2014, to Q2017). Parallels of this form from Mons Claudianus were found in deposits dated to the Antonine period of the 2nd century AD (Knowles 2006, Type, nos 135-141). Roman Ehnasya parallel (Petrie1905, 5, pl. 53) cited on Philadelphia register card. Possibly imported fabric, though photograph resembles local production. The reclining character resembles the pose of Roman period Harpocrates terracotta figures. Knowles, K. 2006. The pottery lamps. In V.A.Maxfield and D.P.S. Peacock, Survey and excavation at Mons Claudianus 1987-1993. Vol.3 Ceramic vessels and related objects. IFAO Cairo. 309–426. Petrie, W.M.Fl. 1905. Roman Ehnasya (Herakleopolis Magna), 1904. London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KE.31) (Phase 3)
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5763 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
